creator: aleoo@solarapex.com
text:
I have a valid svg file:

http://www.solarapex.com/~aleoo/svg/test.svg

that renders a valid PNG image

http://www.solarapex.com/~aleoo/svg/test.png

As result, it generates a this PNG file 

http://www.solarapex.com/~aleoo/svg/test2.png

As you can see, it shows the default image, not the one I want to use.

I use the following command line:

java -jar batik-rasterizer.jar -m image/png test.svg

The amazing thing is it generates the a png file with no complaints or 
exceptions whatsoever.

Other PNG images work fine. I use Sun JDK 1.4.2_03. It can display this image 
using AWT. Adobe SVG Viewer also displays properly.

creator: deweese@apache.org
text:
The problem is that Batik runs out of memory.
The default partition for Java is 32MB your image
is ~16MB which doesn't leave much room for anything
else.  I suggest using the -Xmx option to increase
the maximum amount of memory Java will allocate.
